title: News Corp fires warning shot at Turnbull publisher
text:
News Corp Australia general counsel Ian Philip fired off a terse letter to Sandy Grant on Friday, warning Malcolm Turnbull’s publisher to “carefully consider and check certain matters you may publish”.

Those certain matters worthy of careful consideration are, of course, the disputed accounts of a conversation first related in this column: between Australian media proprietors Rupert Murdoch and Kerry Stokes in the week before Scott Morrison seized the Liberal leadership, in which the Sun King is supposed to have told the Seven chairman that “Malcolm has got to go” and that “I can [still] make money under [Bill] Shorten and the CFMEU”.

Stokes had recounted that conversation to Turnbull (as the former PM detailed on Q &A on November 8), Turnbull’s former deputy Julie Bishop, and others, though, disavowed the version reported by ABC political editor Andrew Probyn.

In February, News Corp co-chairman Lachlan Murdoch told Pamela Williams (then writing for The Monthly) that he was the only other party to the conversation and that “KRM definitely never said ‘Malcolm’s got to go’ or mused on how business would be under a Labor government.”

And now this from Philip: “As you are no doubt aware, Lachlan Murdoch, who was at the relevant meeting, has said that Rupert Murdoch did not make these remarks. Further Kerry Stokes has stated that the reporting of the conversation was wrong.”
description: Presumably, Lachlan Murdoch is the one hypersensitive to the retelling of "Malcolm's got to go".
